abstracts.cdata!:
The Power Sector Reform Technical
            Assistance Project's outcome is rated as marginally
            satisfactory. The main problem areas lie in: a) slow
            progress in implementing National Rural Electrification
            Program; b) failure to privatize the systems in the smaller
            cities; c) the weakness of the National Secretariat of
            Energy; d) several technical disputes related primarily to
            the order of dispatch and the payments due to the generation
            companies; and e) lack of popular understanding and support
            for the reforms. The lessons learned include: 1) A well
            defined legal and regulatory framework, and transparency
            throughout the reform process are prerequisites for
            successful privatization. 2) In smaller cities,
            privatization is likely to be harder to accomplish than in
            major centers. 3) Policy design and implementation are best
            carried out by a strong local core of permanent government
            professionals with a dependable administrative budget. 4)
            Reform of the power sector is a long-term process that
            requires continuous adjustments. 5) When project
            implementation spans a change in administration, allowance
            should be made for at least several months' delay while
            the new administration reviews the situation and determines
            its approach. 6) When preparation of a loan or credit is
            delayed, it is important to have access to other resources.
            7) With the shift to E-mail, assembling all the necessary
            documents for an Implementation Completion Report is
            becoming harder.
